etymologies: late 17th century; earliest use found in Theophilus Gale (1628–1679), ejected minister and theologian. From post-classical Latin boniformis from classical Latin bonus good + -formis, after ancient Greek ἀγαθοειδής (Plato; from ἀγαθός good + -ειδής shaped)

definitions: Of the nature of goodness; forming part of or derived from the Good; cognizant of moral goodness. Frequently (in translations of or with reference to the works of Henry More) in "boniform faculty".
